page.title: 06FARMING - GRAZING
page.content: The sloping ground considered too steep for ploughing is permanent grass /downland and is grazed by sheep and beef cattle which are reared commercially and sold for meat for human consumption. The majority are sold at a local market, alive or dead. The steep grass slopes have very little nitrogen added. The lower parts which are passable with a tractor are given nitrogen in the Spring. Some of the lower fields, to give a crop rotation, are planted with Italian rye grass as a break from cereal crops and are then grazed by sheep, beef cattle, or a dairy herd of cows. Silage or hay is also cut from this rye grass to be used as winter feed for the animals. Other break crops include kale (fed fresh) or winter beans, harvested by combine and used as high-protein supplement feed.
